file_content.text: Our work here is finished. Best you get moving.
How are you feeling?
I've been thawed from carbonite, pierced by twenty-five needles, and injected with something I can only describe as liquid humiliation.
I'm pleased you're doing well.
I'm alright. Did you tell me--I can see stars. Am I on a spaceship?
Yes, you are. You're safe, and you're going to be better soon.
Don't condescend to me.
My apologies. If you'll excuse me--hold transmission, silence audio.
You said we'd all meet back here.
Yes, I lied. She's on her way to a private medical facility. I couldn't be sure you'd approve.
After everything we've been through, you'd still rather manipulate me than trust my judgment.
You should trust me by now.
It's nothing personal. My wife has the same complaint.
Where is she going?
We both have her best interests at heart. Or am I wrong about that?
I want what's best for her.
No, I suppose not.
I'm not your agent anymore, and you're no longer a powerful man. Do you suppose I won't shoot you for lying?
I could kill you, you know.
I don't suppose anything of the sort. But I don't frighten, either.
Shara will be cared for, in secret, by a group of richly compensated medics and scientists.
In a very slow and regrettably painful process, the damage to her brain will be repaired--and her loyalty programming undone.
You can do that?
There are no guarantees. My people say it should be possible.
When she is free, I have advised her not to rejoin the Empire's service and to make a life away from conflict. She's never had that chance before.
After we defeated the Star Cabal, I could've escaped, too. You advised me to keep working for the good of the Empire.
You told me to stay and fight.
She always deserved better than what we could offer.
I'm glad to hear it.
On some level, I think she hated her programming. If I'd known she could be cured...
She couldn't, then. And I know.
Shara Jenn was built by the Empire. Service is the only thing she knows. You'd take her away?
She belongs to the Empire.
Yes.
You signed up to join Imperial Intelligence. You kept fighting after everything that happened. You made choices to continue on your terms.
She never did. I'm giving her that chance.
Talk to her if you like. Say your goodbyes.
Shara? Do you recognize me?
Are you concerned about hibernation blindness or the brain damage?
Of course I recognize you. The Minister--former minister--says you helped me.
I don't want to do this, Cipher. I don't want them to decondition me.
You don't have to be scared. You're not a prisoner. Say the word, and I'll talk to the minister.
No one will force it.
I do have to be scared. The Empire altered my limbic system.
You and I both know why you're saying that. If you could want your freedom, the programming wouldn't be very effective.
It's the conditioning talking.
You're not wrong. It doesn't help very much.
I'm sorry I haven't been there for you, Cipher. Everything else just... got in the way.
And I'm alright--I am. I just don't know who I'll be... without.
Tell me where you are. Look at the stars, listen to the engine--that mind of yours can piece together coordinates.
Help me locate you.
You'd come shooting and take me home to Dromund Kaas? I've got enough sense to say "no."
It's all right, I think--I just don't know who I'll be.
You're the smartest person I've ever met and you're very good at solving mysteries.
I know you'll find the answer.
I have every confidence you'll figure it out.
Maybe. But I hate mysteries.
You'll be the same woman I've admired all this time. The same woman I'd cross the galaxy to protect.
You're someone I care for.
And I thought I'd been the one protecting you.
Shara....
It's enough. Stay and talk--for a little while.
You're going to be a free woman with a brilliant mind and half the secrets of the galaxy. If anyone's going to end this war, it's you.
You're going to save us all.
How many sides of the game do you expect me to play? But I appreciate the confidence.
I'm glad you're here. Stay and talk--for a little while.
You'll be who you've always been. An agent of Imperial Intelligence, by whatever name.
You're an agent of the Empire.
They may get rid of the conditioning, but they can't change your memories. You'll be back.
Maybe so. Stay alive, and I'm sure you'll meet the new me.
I believe our business is done. I have a retirement to get back to--and while I don't expect we'll meet again, I believe I've said that before.
You've more than earned the rest. It's been a pleasure working together one last time.
Enjoy your retirement, sir.
With you as well, agent.
Retired or not, you're going to watch over that woman. You'll see to it that she recovers, and you'll make sure no enemies find her after.
Watch out for Shara.
She's going to live a very peaceful life.
Yes, she will. But don't underestimate her, either.
There is one other thing, by the way.
I'm sorry--did you think you were in control here? That you could walk away whenever you wanted?
We're not finished.
Actually, I thought I could buy you off.
I may be out of the game, but you're not. I hear rumors Intelligence is on the verge of reforming at last.
How do you know that?
I still have a few sources on Dromund Kaas.
Darth Marr wants you to advise and oversee--independent but with full access.
Darth Marr considers my independence to be treason.
Yes--but you'd be a check against any Sith who'd use Intelligence for their own schemes.
Darth Marr intends to divide its command between you and a Sith Lord.
To what end?
You have the experience required, and a Sith will help channel your ambition.
Darth Marr wants you as second-in-command to a Sith Lord.
What Sith Lord?
Those pieces are still being maneuvered.
A new agency will need new personnel to replace those lost. I have files with potential recruits--untraditional but highly skilled.
What kind of untraditional recruits?
Military deserters, terrorist sympathizers and Malgus's alien insurgents. All of them believers in a better Empire.
I'm always glad to have resources, but I'm not making any decisions right now.
I'll take it under advisement.
Don't delay too long. I've heard rumors of new threats.
If we're going to survive, we need everyone who believes in any Empire working together. I'll make sure these recruits are put to good use.
They'll help us reform things.
If I understand the coming threats, you'll need them.
Believers in a different Empire, perhaps--but no part of my Empire.
They'll be cannon fodder.
Still, any new Intelligence will need expendable manpower. Their sacrifices will buy us time to rebuild.
They may be more difficult to cull than you expect. And you will need them.
But as I said--I'm out of the game, and the files are yours.
Watch for enemies within and without. Everything is on you now, and you know the stakes for civilization.
We'd best be off. Good luck.
You're now two meters inside an Umbaran jamming field. If I've pressed the right buttons, we should have adequate privacy.
I received your message for "the Red Blade."
Yes. Perhaps a bit obvious, but I thought your pirate cover appropriate, given the circumstances.
So how is independence suiting you, agent? No one to answer to or interfering with your decisions?
I'm working with Sith more than I expected. But the cause is right, and it's on my terms.
It's keeping me busy.
I'm glad to hear it.
So how are you enjoying authority, agent? You haven't upset the Dark Council, I hope.
My work is in the field, not behind a desk. But it's good to return from an operation and have no one dare to question me.
I have power, now. It's good.
You never did like being assessed.
I know we didn't part on the best of terms, but believe me when I say: I'm glad you're alright.
It's good to see you.
Then perhaps we can table our differences for now.
How are you even here? The Dark Council wanted you killed for disobedience.
So how are the Sith treating you, agent? Still a Cipher without an organization?
All the responsibility and none of the resources. But I'm making do, and the Sith know they need me.
We're getting by.
Let's be grateful for small favors.
I didn't expect we'd ever meet again. I'm glad you called.
It's really good to see you.
I appreciate the sentiment. But I'm sure you understand if I'm not here to socialize.
How are you even alive?
The last time I saw you, you expected to be hanged. You're awfully self-satisfied for a corpse.
You're supposed to be dead.
As it turns out, there was concern that I had arranged for certain documents to be released in the event of my death.
Instead of execution, I was granted early retirement.
Sounds very straightforward.
Very. I assure you, however, I am no longer involved. I've come only to ask a personal favor.
Everything I have is at your disposal, no questions asked. Name the job.
Anything you need.
The Empire is surrounded by enemies. The Republic, now the Revanites... we need people like you.
You should be "involved."
Not anymore. I've accepted my fate, save for some unfinished business.
Given what you did when I took your orders, what makes you think I'd volunteer for anything you propose?
I don't owe you any favors.
To start with, we have a shared interest:
Shara Jenn. The former Keeper and Watcher Two.
Go on.
After the Star Cabal's dissolution, Shara was unwell. The damage to her brain from the cabal's trap had been considerable.
I remember her medical droid. She had trouble speaking.
Add to that her conditioning. She was programmed for loyalty, and we had her working a rogue operation.
That aggravated her existing cognitive and psychogenic trauma. It's fortunate she didn't become a vegetable.
During Lord Malgus's uprising and the chaos that followed, she was unable to protect herself.
What happened?
She was captured by the Republic. I intend to free her.
I'm guessing we're not on Rishi to attack Belsavis prison. How do we get to her?
What's your plan?
Shara saved my life more than once. She was important to me for a long time. I owe her this.
For Shara's sake, I'll help.
As do I.
What does Shara mean to you, that you'd come out of retirement to save her?
Why do you even care?
She was my responsibility. That's enough.
I've made arrangements already. She was carbonite-frozen and placed aboard a prison transport, which was then raided by pirates.
And now the raiders have brought their cargo to Rishi?
Precisely. The final step is to retrieve the body and erase all evidence. No one can know what happened.
I intend to negotiate Shara's purchase from the raiders. While I do, I need you to provide leverage and cover our trail.
It won't be a problem. What kind of leverage am I providing?
Agreed.
Why not a clean sweep? Eliminate the raiders and take Shara. No negotiations, no witnesses.
We could just kill everyone.
People would start asking "why?" The SIS would piece it together. This mission needs to be forgotten, not buried.
Very well. What sort of leverage am I providing?
I'm capable of that. I'll even get you out alive. But then you owe me--understand?
I'll want something in return.
I have information you should appreciate. It's yours after the mission; I expect you'll find it makes us even.
We'll see. What sort of leverage am I providing?
To begin with, I suggest you slice the raiders' databanks and transmit their files to me. That should facilitate negotiations.
I'm sure they've made indiscretions we can use. And after that?
You'll have the frequency to listen in. You know how this works; you'll find what I need.
We can rendezvous here once I've acquired the carbonite.
All right. Let's bring Shara home.
I assure you, this room is secure.
